Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Third National Energy Education Summit: Engineering Connections for Broad Energy Education

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
The need for energy education has never been clearer. Energy services undergird all modern, industrial societies. Despite the fundamental importance of energy, problems of sustainability and reliability afflict the energy industries. The need for a trained workforce and an informed public necessitate improvements in and expansion of education about energy. The 3rd National Energy Education Summit will take place in January of 2018 in Washington, DC. The purpose of the Summit is to engage energy educators, including pre-college, higher education and public education, in sharing best practices and developing partnerships with leaders from business, government and civil society. The Summit will cover what we teach in energy education, how we teach it, how we can collaborate to teach it better, and how we can overcome critical challenges. The Summit builds on a report from the 2016 Summit, available at www.EnergyEducationSummit.org, which presents a vision for energy education in the US.

The emerging meta-field of energy education is in its infancy, but builds on over a century of experience in engineering disciplines including mechanical, chemical, biological, electrical, petroleum and natural gas, and others. Educators who have pioneered the recent expansion of this academic territory have done so largely in isolation without maps to identify pedagogical, instructional, or evaluative approaches particularly well-suited to incorporating energy into the broader landscape of education. Some of the key questions are: How can we best prepare students to be future energy professionals? What combinations of technical knowledge (primarily physics and engineering) and contextual knowledge (economics, societal context, environmental aspects and entrepreneurial skills) are appropriate for students at different levels and fields? The 3rd National Energy Education Summit will serve as a forum for energy, environmental and STEM educators in K-12, higher education, and informal education to gather with leaders from business, industry, government and civil society to share best practices and develop new partnerships in order to expand the scale, impact and effectiveness of energy education. Outcomes of the Summit include building a community of practice in energy education identification of critical learning outcomes and effective practices in key areas of energy education. A report on the Summit will be widely disseminated to inform future efforts in energy education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF grant 1743357 provided partial support for the third National Energy Education Summit held January 25, 2018 near Washington, DC.  More than 80 energy and environmental educators, students and practitioners attended the Summit, organized by The Council of Energy Research and Education Leaders (CEREL) of the National Council for Science and the Environment (NCSE). The Summit was held in conjunction with NCSE’s 18th National Conference on Science, Policy and the Environment which had a theme: The Science, Business and Education of Sustainable Infrastructure: Building Resilience in a Changing World.

 

The 3rd National Energy Education Summit report available at www.energyeducationsummit.org presents key perspectives and presentations on energy education in the US, including energy literacy of citizens and students from K-12 to undergraduate, graduate and professional education.

 

Tom Richard, Ph.D., Professor and Director, Institutes of Energy and the Environment, Penn State University and President of CEREL noted, “Our theme this year is “Education for Resilient Energy Systems”. Building on the resilience focus at the National Council on Science and the Environment (NCSE)’s National Conference and Global Forum earlier this week, today we will be taking a deep dive into what resilience means for energy systems, and how we can educate the next generation of energy professionals to achieve energy security, reliability, and sustainability.”

 

The Summit developed ideas and partnerships for advancing energy education in K-12 programs, promoting a culture of energy efficiency, and through development of degrees, minors, certificates and concentrations. It explored connections between engineering and society, energy and climate, between campus and community, between energy and sustainability and among diverse populations. It discussed best practices in teaching and how to prepare future professionals.

Participants concluded that energy education is an emerging interdisciplinary field that needs a clearer vision and increased collaboration among educators, employers and other stakeholders. They identified the biggest needs in energy education and workforce preparation as:

•             A better understanding across all education levels of what energy IS, where it comes from (both finite and renewable), how it is stored, transferred, and used.

•             Understanding of connections between technological and other factors: institutional, ecological, socio-economic, policy and larger narratives such as sustainability and equity.

•             Students will require skill in systems thinking to understand the complex interaction of energy systems, technologies, policies and regulations, and emerging market structures.

•             Teaching flexibility and that everything is always evolving, changing, and connected

•             Recognized programs for education about sustainable energy.

•             Linkages between education and practice, including practical experiences.

An increased emphasis on energy education and workforce preparation will have considerable payoffs in a more informed society capable of making better choices about energy and with a energy and environmental workforce that will increase national security, economic competitiveness and sustainability.
